doc.title: STX NDR Takeaway: Industry Remains Healthy, HAMR Checking all the Boxes
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/Seagate Technology plc STX NDR Takeaways Industry Remains Healthy HAMR Checking all the BoxesSeagate Technology plc STX _2025-08-28

passages.text: Seagate Technology plc
With the stock at all- time highs, we walk away from some time on the road feeling good about the HDD industry and the health of the HAMR ramp.

HDD demand signals remain strong, there is currently more industry demand than supply, and customers are trying to secure drives more than a year out. 1H CY25 HAMR ramp consists largely of shipments to GOOGL but the 2H is still on track to expand to 2 more (we think one is MSFT). Management is on track to qualify all the remaining CSPs by the 1H of CY26, with subsequent shipments 3 quarters after each is qualified. The next generation at 4TB/platter started qualifications with a leading cloud customer in July (likely GOOGL) and remains on track for mass production in 1H26. This means initial 40TB shipments coming by the end of next year. The bear case is that EB growth has intersected the LT trajectory, however the company is striking a positive tone and it seems like the market is still supply constrained vs. facing demand challenges.
STX:Quarterly and Annual EPS (USD)

Price (27-Aug-2025) USD 167.24 Price Target USD 180.00
The HDD market is improving as industry participants use pricing to their advantage and the HAMR technology transition leads to capacity gains.
Our upside case of \(210 is based upon 18x our upside CY26E EPS of\) 11.50, which assumes a faster than expected ramp of HAMR with continued positive pricing trends.
Our downside case of \(125 is based upon 14x our downside CY26E EPS of\) 9.00, which assumes a slower than expected ramp in HAMR and worse than expected pricing trends.
Upside/Downside scenarios
Reiterates AD target with HAMR at \(40\%\) of NL exabyte mix exiting FY26 and crossover point in 1H FY27.
HAMR has only shipped to GOOGL through the 1H of CY25. Management expects to ship to the two- th qualified customers in the 2H of CY25.
Seees 8 CSPs in total including Chinese customers. 3 are already qualified with the remainder qualified by 1H CY26.

HAMR can be utilized in both a CMR version and a SMR format. Near the end of the production process the customer will indicate to STX which type of configuration they plan to use and STX will make the firmware changes required to enable the device type. Customer internal software enables CMR vs. SMR drives.

HAMR drives can be mixed and matched with PMR drives if the deployment type is cohesive. For instance, a CMR HAMR drive can work in the same deployment as a CMR PMR drive but will not work with a SMR PMR drive.
Started qualification on 4TB/platter drive with one customer in July (we think GOOGL) and reiterated expect mass production in 1H of CY26.

HAMR drives take 9 months to qualify. HAMR lead times are roughly 9 months vs. historical HDD lead times of 6 months. HAMR takes longer to manufacture due to more steps involved in the wafer fabrication process for HAMR heads and increased testing time.

HAMR lasers are all external at 30TB per drive. At 40TB per drive, there will be a mix of both external and internal lasers. Internal lasers provide a mild cost advantage but the company intends to utilize a mix of internal and external lasers for diversity of supply.

Plans on increasing total exabyte capacity beyond the 160EB point while keeping units relatively flat. The increase in total exabytes is due to mix shift towards higher capacity drives which is better TCO for the customer and margin accretive for STX.
The industry currently has more demand than supply. Reiterated LT DC EB CAGR of mid- 20s and expects demand to be slightly above this range.

Long term capex should remain at target levels of \(4 - 6\%\) of revenue. This capex is mostly for maintenance and in some cases for the HAMR specific manufacturing tools, but it is not greenfield spend.

Pricing generally increasing on a like- for- like base with older product generations. On newer generations of products, STX gives a discount on a price per TB basis the first time they sell the new product (total pricing still increases because of total capacity increases).
BTO strategy gives them about 4 quarters of visibility. Customers want to put build plans in for a longer period but STX wants to hold at 12 months.

In BTO strategy, they do not start booking orders until they are qualified on a product. When customers qualify new HAMR products it will take 3 quarters to ship to that customer because of the lead time.
For non- DC business, think longer term Consumer, VIA, and NAS are relatively stable while Client and Mission Critical decline.
- \(16\%\) is the right way to think about the tax rate going forward.
Our CY25 revenue/EPS remain unchanged at \(9765M / 89.40\) , and CY26 remains unchanged at \(10,480M / 10.40\) .

Our price target of \(180 is based upon 17x our CY26E EPS of\) 10.40. Our prior price target of \(125 was based upon 12x our CY26E EPS of\) 10.40. We raise our multiple to reflect growing confidence in the HAMR technology transition and continued signs of strong end demand.

Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.
